#Text=The Man Who Believed in Miracles

#Text=Once upon a time a traveler arrived in a land quite like our own , full of modern technology like cars and computers and whistling teapots , but with these two differences : there were no television sets and no airplanes .
#Text=In fact , nothing at all had ever been seen in the sky , not even a bird , and the only movies the people ever saw were in the theaters .
#Text=The traveler stayed for about a month on the eastern shore where he had arrived , and then decided to visit the western cities .
#Text=He mentioned his decision one evening at a meeting of the principal scientists and educators of the region , who had gathered to hear of his travels .
#Text=Someone mentioned that the west had much to offer , but that the journey between the two areas was unpleasant , consisting of crossing a hot , empty desert .
#Text=" In that case , " said the traveler , " I 'll just fly . "
#Text=" Is that like sleep ? " one of the scientists asked .
#Text=" No , no , " the traveler replied .
#Text=" You know , fly through the air , like a bird . "
#Text=" And what is a bird ? " someone asked .
#Text=And so the traveler began to explain about flight and what an airplane was and how it flew from one place to another .
#Text=The room became very quiet , and the expressions on the faces of everyone present darkened .
#Text=" Does he expect us to believe this ? "
#Text=one man whispered to another .
#Text=" Well , you know what liars travelers are , " someone else added .
#Text=Finally the host spoke up , slightly embarrassed and slightly indignant .
#Text=" If this is your idea of a joke , " he began , but was interrupted by the surprised traveler .
#Text=" Why , it 's no joke at all .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= I am sorry that you so much underestimate the intelligence and learning of your audience , " said a professor across the table .

column1: #Text=" That a person could enter some metal device -- like a car with fins -- and rise into the air , and be sustained there , and move forward , why that clearly violates everything we know about the law of gravity and the laws of physics .

#Text=If we have learned anything from a thousand years of study of the natural world , it is that an object heavier than air must return immediately to earth when it is tossed into the sky .

_	_	_	_

#Text= Hear , hear , " two or three people muttered .

column1: #Text=" Now , if you perhaps mean that these ' airplanes , ' as you call them , are somehow flung into the air for a short distance and then fall to the ground , well , then perhaps that would be possible . "
#Text=The professor looked expectantly and a bit condescendingly at the traveler , hoping that the man would take this face-saving opportunity .
#Text=" No , no .

#Text= The airplanes have powerful motors and the craft rise into the air , and they stay up as long as they want , as long as the fuel holds out . "

column1: #Text=There were several audible " hmmphs " around the room .
#Text=" Tell us then , " said another scholar , in a saccharine voice , " how this device works .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= Well , I do n't know exactly how it works .

_	_	_	_

#Text= You do n't know -- you cannot explain -- how it works , this device that runs counter to everything we know about the natural world , yet you believe in it anyway . "

column1: #Text=" Believe in it ? " asked the traveler , a bit confused by this turn of phrase .
#Text=" Of course I ' believe in it . '

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= And how do you control its motions ? " a man asked , without removing his pipe .

column1: #Text=The audience was clearly beginning to patronize the traveler , and he was growing a little irritated .
#Text=" Oh , I do n't control it .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= I see , " the pipe smoker said .

column1: #Text=" So this airplane contains both you and the pilot .

#Text=You 're telling us that perhaps four or five hundred pounds of dead weight can travel through the air as long as it wants .

_	_	_	_

#Text= As long as the fuel holds out , " added one of the hmmphers , with amusement .

column1: #Text=" And all the time sneering at the law of gravity and laughing science in the face , " someone else noted .
#Text=" Well , actually , the planes are much larger than that , " said the traveler .
#Text=" Many of them hold two or three hundred people and weigh , my , I do n't know -- many thousands of pounds . "
#Text=" I think we have heard enough , " the now-fully-embarrassed and half-angered host said .
#Text=" It was amusing for awhile , but it 's time to put an end to this nonsense . "
#Text=" It is not nonsense , " the traveler protested .
#Text=" It is the truth . "
#Text=" Then you really believe this madman 's drivel you 've been feeding us ? " the host asked , rather hotly .
#Text=" Of course .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= Obviously faked , " said the host , dismissing it after a glance .

column1: #Text=" Who invited this charlatan ? " someone asked of no one in particular .
#Text=" I thought science had put an end to all this miraculous event stuff long ago , " said another man , rising from his chair and preparing to leave .
#Text=" Well , let 's not pursue this pointless discussion , " the host said .
#Text=" Our guest apparently knows nothing of science , and is impervious to logic and to the considered opinion of the best minds of our nation .
